content.text: Move the 1.50 N load to a distance \(d=40.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from the 0.0 cm end of the ruler.
Raise or lower one clamp slightly, if necessary, so that the metre ruler is as near to horizontal as possible.
Read the value \(F_{X}\) on force meter \(X\) and the value \(F_{Y}\) on force meter \(Y\).
Calculate a value \(W_{X}\) using the equation \(W_{X}=F_{X}+F_{Y}-k\), where \(k=1.50 \mathrm{~N}\).
Briefly describe how to check that the ruler is horizontal before taking the reading. You may draw a diagram.
Move the 1.50 N load to a distance \(d=10.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from the 0.0 cm end of the ruler. Ensure that the metre ruler is as near to horizontal as possible.
Read, and record in Table 1.1, the value \(F_{X}\) on force meter \(X\).
Repeat this procedure for \(d=30.0 \mathrm{~cm}, 50.0 \mathrm{~cm}, 70.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) and 90.0 cm.
Plot a graph of \(F_{X} / \mathrm{N}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(d / \mathrm{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start the axes at the origin \((0,0)\).
Draw a best-fit straight line.
From your graph, determine \(F_0\), the value of \(F_X\) when \(d=0.0 \text{ cm}\).
Calculate the weight \(W_R\) of the metre ruler, using the equation \(W_R = 2 \times F_0\).
State and explain whether your plots made it easy to choose the best-fit line.
Justify your answer with reference to your plots.
[Total: 11]
BLANK PAGE
In this experiment, you will investigate a suspended metre ruler and determine the weight of the metre ruler.
Refer to Fig. 1.1. Do not change the position of the loops of thread attached to the force meters.
Measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer.
Describe **one** technique for ensuring that this reading is accurate.
Pour \(200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into the beaker.
Place the thermometer into the water in the beaker.
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t=0\) and immediately start the stop-watch.
Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30 s until \(t=270 \mathrm{~s}\).
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90 \text { s }\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t=0\) and \(t=90 \text { s }\).
Include the unit for the cooling rate.
\[x_{1}=\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots \quad [1]\]
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the middle 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90 \text { s }\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t=90 \text { s }\) and \(t=180 \text { s }\).
\[x_{2}=\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots \quad [1]\]
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{3}\) during the last 90 s of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T=90 \text { s }\) and \(\theta_{180}\) and \(\theta_{270}\) are the temperatures at \(t=180 \text { s }\) and \(t=270 \text { s }\).
\[x_{3}=\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots \quad [1]
The temperature of the water decreases over time.
Use your results from (c) to describe the overall pattern of the rate of cooling of the water in the experiment. Justify your answer by reference to your results.
Estimate the final temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the water after several hours.
\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}=\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots \quad [1]
Another student does the same experiment. She starts with the hot water at a lower initial temperature.
Suggest how her cooling rates are likely to compare with yours. Use your results to explain your answer.
State one variable, other than initial water temperature, that the student needs to control.
[Total: 11]
BLANK PAGE
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in a beaker.
Refer to Fig. 2.1.
Disconnect \(\mathrm{R}_{2}\) from circuit A. Resistor \(\mathrm{R}_{1}\) remains connected between terminals P and Q, as shown in Fig. 3.2.
Repeat the procedures in (a)(i) and (a)(ii).
Connect \(\mathrm{R}_{2}\) in series with \(\mathrm{R}_{1}\) between terminals P and Q, as shown in Fig. 3.3.
Repeat the procedures in (a)(i) and (a)(ii).
Briefly explain why resistor \(R_{p}\), shown in Fig. 3.1, must remain in place throughout the experiment.
\(R_{p}\) has a resistance of \(3 \Omega\). Use your values in Table 3.1 to support your answer.
A student determines the resistance of \(R_{1}\). He uses a variable resistor in circuit B to control the current and draws a graph of \(V\) against \(I\).
Briefly explain one advantage of using a variable resistor to control the current.
[Total: 11]
BLANK PAGE
In this experiment, you will investigate circuits containing different combinations of resistors.
Circuit A has been set up for you.
Refer to Fig. 3.1.
**Resistor \(\mathbf{R_{p}}\) must remain in place throughout the experiment.**
A student investigates the refraction of light.
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1.
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel.
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration.
Concentration is measured in \(\text{g/cm}^3\).
You are **not** required to do the experiment.
The apparatus available includes:

samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations
 a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light.
In your plan:
list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take
state the key variable to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
BLANK PAGE
